Situation1: They prepare a structured session to teach important skills before a project deadline.
Expectation2: Ensure client satisfaction and address any concerns or complaints professionally
Situation2: An easygoing regular politely asks for a tiny adjustment to their fringe.
Story: I glanced at the clock, heart thumping. In ten minutes, my mentees would gather in the back room, expecting the session I’d promised—an organized walkthrough of the skills they’d need for the looming project deadline. I’d spent hours preparing slides and notes, determined to give them the guidance I wished I’d had. But right now, scissors in hand, I was finishing up with Mrs. Lee, my favorite regular. She smiled at her reflection, then hesitated. “Could you just trim the fringe a bit more? It’s poking my eyes.” Her tone was gentle, but I knew she valued every detail. I glanced at the clock again. If I took the extra time, I’d be late for the session, letting down my mentees. If I rushed Mrs. Lee, I’d risk her trust and satisfaction. My mind spun with the weight of both roles—mentor and hairdresser—each demanding my full attention, each expecting me to deliver. I felt the pressure mounting, torn between sharing my knowledge and ensuring my client left happy, both impossible to do perfectly at the same time.
